message: You're invited to join Rep. Deutch at his Boca Raton Town Hall meeting on Thursday, August 31st at 10:30 A.M.
You're invited to join Congressman Ted Deutch for his Town Hall meeting and community discussion in Wilton Manors.  The Pride Center 2040 N Dixie Hwy Wilton Manors, FL Sunday, February 12 2:00 PM

As I wrote in the Sun Sentinel's #SouthFlorida100 this week, I’m returning to Washington ready and motivated to focus on the issues important to South Florida. I’ll fight attempts to weaken Medicare and cut Social Security. I’ll work with my colleagues and our business community to spur job growth and innovation. I’ll continue my bipartisan efforts to act on climate change. I’ll stand strongly for full equality for the LGBT community, the protection of women’s reproductive rights, and the need to reform our criminal justice system. And we will work to strengthen our national security and enhance the U.S.-Israel relationship.

Gutting the independent and nonpartisan ethics office should not be acceptable to anyone of any political party.  Yet this is what was done on the night before a new Congress is sworn in?  Hopefully, a good night's sleep, together with growing outrage across the political spectrum, will cause Speaker Ryan to reconsider this one before it's too late.   http://mobile.nytimes.com/2017/01/02/us/politics/with-no-warning-house-republicans-vote-to-hobble-independent-ethics-office.html?emc=edit_na_20170102&nlid=53065648&ref=cta&_r=0&referer=

As a member of the House Ethics Committee, I understand the importance of independent ethics investigations. Here's my take on House Republicans' attempt to undermine the Office of Congressional Ethics.

As Members of the House of Representatives filed to the floor this morning to read from the Constitution, I urged my colleagues to support my effort to overturn the U.S. Supreme Court's Citizens United decision by passing a constitutional amendment, the 28th Amendment, on campaign finance reform.

Awful news from the Fort Lauderdale Airport. I've spoken with TSA, law enforcement, and local leaders. Shooter in custody. My thoughts and prayers go out to the victims and their families. Our community will be there for one another at this really difficult time.

Here's the latest on the #FLLShooting.   It's been 24 hours since yesterday's tragic events at the Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. We mourn the loss of human life in this awful shooting and keep the victims' family members, the injured, and all those affected in our thoughts. We are grateful to Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel and the Broward Sheriff's Office, together with federal, state, and local law enforcement, all of the first responders, the trauma doctors and other health professionals, Red Cross volunteers, government employees, and community members who have come together to support everyone impacted. We will learn more as the investigation continues and will respond as necessary, in the courts and in Congress.   As of 10:00 a.m. Saturday, the airport is open and some flights have resumed. Terminal 2 check-in and ticket counters are open, but baggage claim remains closed. Some flights are being rerouted or canceled, so be sure to check with your airline. Roadways leading to the airport are open.  If you are a friend or family member and are seeking information about an airport passenger that was at the airport during the incident, please call 1-866-435-9355 or 954-831-4000. Continue to check back as more information becomes available.  You can also follow Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport’s twitter handle (@FLLFlyer) and follow the hashtag #FLLUPDATE for up-to-date information, including how to claim personal items left during the evacuation.  The Broward Sheriff’s Office has also set up an alert system. You can sign up to receive alerts at http://www.sheriff.org/apps/ealerts.  To reach our office, please email DeutchOffice@mail.house.gov. For press inquiries, please contact Jason.Attermann@mail.house.gov.

Who benefits from the Affordable Care Act's protections? It's not just the 20 million Americans newly covered by plans on Healthcare.gov; the law also improved coverage for the 150 million Americans enrolled in plans through their employer, the 55 million disabled Americans and seniors covered by Medicare, and the over 74 million low-income families enrolled in Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program.  What could repeal of the health care law mean? It could mean that your grandmother will pay more for her prescription drugs, or that your niece in graduate school on a limited budget will no longer be able to afford contraceptives, or that your friend's cancer treatment will be interrupted when coverage is pulled because of her pre-existing condition. It could undermine our efforts to stop the onslaught of drug overdose deaths claiming six lives every week in Broward County by allowing insurance companies to arbitrarily refuse to cover mental health and substance abuse services.  Read my op-ed in today's Sun Sentinel for more on why I firmly oppose Republicans' efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

Today's terror attack in Jerusalem reminds us that while the UN debates resolutions, Israel faces real threats every day.  We mourn the loss of innocent life as we stand with Israel.   https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/four-israeli-soldiers-killed-in-truck-attack-in-jerusalem/2017/01/08/08088234-d599-11e6-9a36-1d296534b31e_story.html

This disturbing and frightening news of terror threats against Jewish institutions in South Florida and across the country remind us of the need to be vigilant and ensure that our communities have the resources to meet increasing security demands. The partnership between the Department of Homeland Security, FBI and state and local law enforcement is critical.  http://www.timesofisrael.com/bomb-threats-made-at-jccs-in-6-states-hundreds-evacuated/

Just last week, the House of Representatives observed a moment of silence to mark the 6th anniversary of the Tucson shooting. I never expected that today, so soon after, we’d be observing another such moment, and for a tragedy so close to home.  We cannot accept a world in which we don’t have time to mourn lives lost in one shooting before another occurs. After the tragedy last summer at Pulse nightclub, after the many stories I’ve heard from constituents affected by gun violence, and now even more than ever after Friday’s shooting at the Fort Lauderdale airport, I want no more of these tragedies in my community. I want no more of this unbearable pain in any community. Inaction is no longer an acceptable response.  Sadly, there is now a routine that Congress follows: shocking news of a deadly shooting, followed by conveyance of thoughts and prayers, followed by a moment of silence on the House floor. These moments of silence are a respectful way to reflect on the lives that were taken so tragically. But to truly honor the victims of this and other gun violence, moments of silence must be followed by productive discussions on what meaningful actions should be taken to address the crisis of gun violence.   We must figure out how to get treatment for people with mental illness. We must also keep guns out of the hands of the mentally ill, and we must prevent potential terrorists from getting their hands on dangerous weapons. If we can’t take these simple, sensible first steps, we will never succeed in preventing shootings like this in the future. Thoughts and prayers will be all we have to give, and that's just not enough.
Earlier this week I pleaded for my House Republican colleagues to meet with me and start a conversation on sensible, bipartisan steps to curb gun violence. We cannot continue to remain silent.

Following Trump's press conference yesterday, I appeared on CNN to discuss the President-elect's conflicts of interest. The plan Trump laid out fails every ethics test. Every modern president has complied with the Ethics in Government Act, and every president is bound by the foreign bribery clause of the U.S. Constitution. President-elect Trump should be no different.

There are so many issues we deal with in Congress that need to rise above partisanship. Regardless of which party is in the majority or who is in the White House, caring for seniors and standing up for veterans should never become subject to partisan politics. That’s why I’ve worked with Republican colleagues like Rep. Vern Buchanan, Rep. Tom Rooney, and Senator Marco Rubio to introduce this package of bills and to protect our veterans and our seniors.

I’m on my way to the House Floor now for the last votes of the week. I'm going to vote no on repealing the Affordable Care Act, especially when there is nothing to replace it. It's a reckless step that will hurt families who will lose coverage, seniors on Medicare whose prescriptions will cost more, and everyone whose insurance policies will be stripped of ACA-required consumer protections against insurance company abuses.

Join me, Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, and Congressman Alcee L. Hastings in Sunrise tomorrow for a community forum in support of the Affordable Care Act. Find more details and RSVP in the event below.
Dr. King told us that we must measure ourselves by where we stand at times of challenge and controversy. I stand with those who march for his powerful vision of  justice and equality for all. #MLKday

Today I was honored to recognize a member of our community for her selfless activism by presenting Johanna Kandel with the Community Voice Award. Johanna's work as the founder of the Alliance for Eating Disorders Awareness led to Congress's passage of the first ever federal legislation on eating disorders last year. I've been so moved by her efforts, and I know she has inspired others to find their voice as well. Congrats to all of today's honorees who are on the front lines of a battle to help the public understand mental illness, erase the stigma, and ensure people can get the care they need.

The startling news of two bomb threats in as many weeks against Jewish institutions should disturb all of us. We will not be intimidated or bullied way from the places where we have gathered safely as a community, including JCCs. The partnership between the Department of Homeland Security, FBI, and local law enforcement to protect our communities is more important than ever.

It was an honor to be sworn in today in Broward and Palm Beach with my family, members of our community, and my colleagues Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Rep. Lois Frankel by my side. Thanks to the city and county officials and judges for officiating, the SD Spady Elementary School choir for the music, and everyone else who participated at the Fort Lauderdale Courthouse and Delray City Hall.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) reports that 2016 was the hottest year on record, the third consecutive record-breaking year. Temperatures will continue to rise more and more quickly, threatening global ecosystems, international security, and natural resources. Sea level rise will continue to inundate coastal communities worldwide, including those in South Florida. Governments will be forced to spend millions in short-term efforts to mitigate the negative effects of climate change.   Many Republicans understand this reality and want to take action, including Miami-Dade Mayor Giménez and Rep. Carlos Curbelo, my Republican co-chair of the Climate Solutions Caucus. Even many of President-elect Trump’s cabinet nominees testified before the Senate this week that they recognize the reality of climate change. Partisan bickering on this issue will do nothing to solve this very real, threatening problem. It’s time we focus on the facts and hold officials accountable in relying on and responding to the best science available. We can wait no longer to work together to find economically-viable, bipartisan solutions.
Thank you for your leadership, your humility and your grace. God bless you, and God bless America.

I was proud to stand with women in West Palm Beach today as their ally and as a proud feminist. Millions worldwide and thousands in West Palm joined together for a #WomensMarch to support women's rights, reproductive rights, equality for all, and freedom from hate.   Today was about justice and respect and humanity. It was also about accountability and activism. Today and every day.

On the 44th anniversary of Roe v Wade, I remain committed to protecting a woman's right to make her own health decisions. House Republicans are already planning to introduce legislation that would restrict this right. Instead of turning back the clock to a dangerous time for women's health, we should be repealing the discriminatory Hyde Amendment, protecting access to contraceptives under the Affordable Care Act, and supporting Planned Parenthood Centers nationwide.

If President Trump doesn't commit to serious action on climate change and supporting investments in renewable energy sources, he doesn't just threaten to reverse the progress we've made globally; he will leave American companies at a global disadvantage and weaken our standing around the world.  This is no longer just about science; it's about our competitive, economic standing around the world.

The Supreme Court’s disastrous Citizens United decision reserved meaningful political participation for the rich and wealthy special interests. At every turn and on nearly every issue, from gun safety to climate change, unlimited political spending ensures that Congress is tuned in to the needs of special interests and tunes out the voices of the American people. It’s time to get money out of politics to guard our elections against a dangerous threat that erodes the faith of the American people in our democratic institutions.  That's why today, I reintroduced the Democracy for All Amendment along with my colleagues Congressman Jim McGovern, Rep. Jamie Raskin, Senator Tom Udall, and Senator Michael Bennet. This constitutional amendment would help to reverse the concentration of political influence held by large corporations and the wealthiest Americans capable of spending millions of dollars in American elections. To help get big money out of politics and restore democratic power to the American people, this amendment would affirm the right of the people to pass state and federal laws regulating spending in elections.
Watch for my thoughts on actions taken by Trump and House Republicans this week in Washington.

Yesterday, I was selected to serve as Ranking Member on the House Ethics Committee. I am committed to ensuring that meeting the highest ethical standards remains a focus of the House and that the members of the House keep their commitments to those they were elected to serve. I'm honored and humbled to serve in this role.  I am also proud to have been re-elected to serve as Ranking Member on the Middle East and North Africa Subcommittee. From guaranteeing Israel’s security and ensuring strict compliance with the Iran nuclear deal to calling attention to the human rights abuses of the Assad regime and fighting terrorist groups like ISIS, I look forward to continuing the bipartisan work we achieved last Congress with my colleague Chairman Ros-Lehtinen.

This week I spoke on the House floor in opposition to a bill that would block women's rights to make their own decisions about their bodies and health care. The House GOP majority chose to ignore the voices of the millions of women who had marched just days earlier by voting on a bill that says, "your bodies, Washington's rules."

At a time when anti-Semitism is surging around the world and attacks on Jewish communities are almost daily occurrences, it’s even more important that the world remember the horrors of the Holocaust when six million Jews died and put into practice the lessons from this dark period of history. We must raise our voices against injustice, protest bigotry and intolerance, and demand action in the face of humanitarian crises and widespread violence.   International Holocaust Remembrance Day is also an opportunity to recommit ourselves to the promises made to Survivors to provide them with the care and support they need in their senior years. We must continue to work with the German Government to ensure that Survivors receive the support they need to live their final years in dignity and comfort.   Today should also serve as a reminder to countries that have not yet enacted restitution laws that they should follow through on their pledge under the Terezin Declaration to compensate victims of Nazi persecution and their families for stolen property.

Our nation has a proud history of welcoming refugees from around the world fleeing horrific conditions in their home countries, and escaping extreme violence and persecution to seek safety in the United States.  In a direct attack on this proudly American value, the President’s executive order on refugees starts a period in which the United States closes its doors to the most vulnerable people, including children, seeking safety in our country.   Our top priority is guaranteeing the safety and security of the American people, and I believe we need a thorough and comprehensive vetting process for all people seeking asylum or refuge.   However, the President’s decision - to slam the door on all refugees for four months and Muslim refugees indefinitely, and to cut by more than half the number of refugees seeking safe haven this year - will leave thousands of vulnerable families and children around the world in limbo, leaving them to suffer horrific atrocities and persecution.   This will mean the LGBT individual from Uganda or any country that criminalizes homosexuality, and the thousands of Baha’i, Jewish, Christian, and Muslim refugees persecuted in Iran, would continue to live in fear of persecution without any hope of being welcomed in our country where Lady Liberty’s torch will no longer light a path toward freedom.   This Executive Order will not strengthen our national security, but it will leave thousands of families vulnerable to violence and suffering. Our nation has shut its doors to those fleeing violence before. We should not return to those days.  http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-trump-refugees-20170127-story.html

Just got back to DC a little while ago and headed straight to the Supreme Court. A huge crowd was already there - standing up for an America that never slams the door on refugees fleeing horrific violence.

For the third time in a month, Jewish institutions across the country received bomb threats. Fortunately, local law enforcement investigations confirmed that there was no immediate danger. But the damage remains: Jewish communities – from the parents who send their children to daycare to the seniors who rely on services provided – are now forced to live on high alert, fearful that the next time won’t just be a threat. This cannot be acceptable to anyone in our community, regardless of their religion. We must all remain vigilant.

Mitch McConnell defied history by blocking President Obama’s pick for the Supreme Court for almost a year, and his unprecedented move has now paid off with President Trump's nomination of an extreme right-wing ideologue.   Judge Neil Gorsuch's radical views on federal regulations fly in the face of long-standing Supreme Court precedent and will undermine crucial consumer protections, environmental protections, and labor safety protections. He sided with corporations in the Hobby Lobby decision defining them as people, giving corporations the right to deny women birth control in the name of religious belief. He has publicly attacked everyday Americans for seeking access to our nation’s courts to protect and support their individual rights. His rulings supporting the use of excessive force by law enforcement will be a step-back in our nation’s effort to reform the criminal justice system. And he has consistently sided with corporations and their interests while quashing the ability of employees to protect their rights in the workplace.   If Mitch McConnell wanted to replace the late Justice Scalia with someone with equally or even more extreme views, he’s getting the pick he wanted. Judge Gorsuch’s far-right views fall so far outside the mainstream that he should not be confirmed for a lifetime appointment to the nation's highest court.

The House could be addressing the issues the American people care about. Instead, today we are voting on repealing anti-corruption protections that hold both private industry and the government accountable to taxpayers.

Today I was joined by Bradley Whitford, who you may know as Josh Lyman from the show The West Wing, to discuss the importance of addressing climate change. One year after Rep. Carlos Curbelo and I founded the bipartisan Climate Solutions Caucus, membership is at 20 Members of Congress and growing.   With all the challenges that we face, I'm proud to cochair this bipartisan effort to combat climate change. I'm grateful for the help of Citizens Climate Lobby activists like Bradley. With their help, I believe we will make positive progress for the future of our planet.

I welcome today’s announcement from the Treasury Department that sanctions will be imposed on 13 individuals and 12 companies following Iran’s latest ballistic missile launch on January 29. Acting Treasury Secretary Adam Szubin has been instrumental in ensuring Iran is held accountable for its continued and repeated violations of international law and I am pleased to see his good work carrying over in the new Administration. Even as we continue to vigorously enforce the nuclear agreement, we must make clear that Iran’s pursuit of dangerous missile and terrorist activities will not be tolerated. I hope the United Nations will follow today’s sanctions with swift international action.

I’m incredibly disappointed, though not surprised, that the House voted yesterday to repeal regulations that help keep guns out of the hands of individuals with violent, unmanaged mental illness. The days of the NRA bullying Congress and undermining efforts to end the gun violence epidemic must come to an end. Tragedy after tragedy will continue to devastate families and communities until Republicans join Democrats in standing up and taking action.

I disagree with many of the policies supported by President Trump’s nominee for the Department of Education, Betsy DeVos. I'm particularly alarmed that hours before the Senate's final confirmation vote, she has left many conflicts of interest unresolved. Like Trump, DeVos has not taken necessary actions to divest from her numerous business holdings. Our nation deserves a strong public school system run by a fully-vetted Secretary of Education who works with students’ and teachers' best interests in mind, not her financial assets.   I stand with the Senators tonight opposing DeVos’ confirmation, and I urge more Republican Senators to vote against her tomorrow.

Admiral Mullen, who served in Democratic and Republican administrations, is right about Steve Bannon. Last week, I led 50 of my Democratic colleagues in demanding that President Trump remove Bannon from the Principals Committee of the National Security Council and reinstate the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Director of National Intelligence. In making this appointment, the President made clear that he prioritizes the advice of Bannon, whose reckless and irresponsible comments on global affairs could have disastrous implications for our foreign policy and our national security decisions. Protecting the safety and security of all Americans should be the President's highest priority, not rewarding unqualified political allies who have championed the racist, anti-Semitic and anti-Muslim alt-right movement.  President Trump must reverse this indefensible move and bring back the informed judgment of our national security leaders to the Principals Committee.

Most of you know how passionate I am about animal welfare issues. In fact, I was the only congressperson from Florida to receive a 100+ score from the The Humane Society of the United States for my 2016 voting record.   Today, I'm excited to share the news that I'm about to reintroduce the PACT Act. This bipartisan legislation would finally make cruelty against animals, including Prudence here, a federal offense.

I'm excited to announce four new members of the Climate Solutions Caucus today. Caucus membership is now 24 and growing, evenly split between Democrats and Republicans.  Across the country, Americans understand the urgency of climate change. Whether they see rising tides in Fort Lauderdale, intensifying tornadoes along the Central Plains, or worsening droughts affecting farm production, Americans are starting to feel the impacts of climate change to their homes, their livelihoods, and their wallets. They want action from their elected officials, and I’m proud that this Caucus offers a space to develop bipartisan solutions.  Rep. Carlos Curbelo and I are pleased to welcome Congressman Dave Reichert, Congressman Earl Blumenauer, Congressman Don Bacon, and Congressman Charlie Crist.

The law is clear: public officials cannot use their positions or offices for private gain.   Last night, President Trump used his official Twitter account to attack Nordstrom over his daughter’s clothing line. This morning, Kellyanne Conway gave a “free commercial” on TV and used her position as a senior White House official to tell people to “go buy Ivanka’s stuff.”   President Trump and his Administration continue to blatantly violate ethics laws. Trump clearly is still focused on his family business and name brand, and he’s shown us nothing to believe that he will put the nation’s interests above his own finances.   Tune in tomorrow morning at 7:40 a.m. to hear me discuss this with Tim Farley on Siriux/XM’s POTUS station.

Today I went on CNBC's "Squawk on the Street" to discuss the Trump Administration's blatant disregard of ethics laws. Presidents and their advisers are legally prohibited from using their position as public servants to promote their financial interests. President Trump should stop tweeting about his family business and focus exclusively on the American brand rather than the Trump brand.

It was great to join local business leaders and job creators at the Fort Lauderdale Chamber of Commerce's 107th annual meeting and discuss the importance of local job growth.  At the meeting Arnold Donald, the CEO of Carnival Cruiselines, announced that the company has made a greater commitment to Port Everglades than any other port worldwide. That's the kind of investment we need to encourage in Fort Lauderdale, which is why I've proudly supported continued federal funding for the Port's expansion.   Congrats to all of today's honorees and speakers.

Thanks to all who attended my Town Hall meeting in Pompano Beach today. It was great to hear your thoughts on so many important issues facing our state and nation, including ways we can support our veterans, the President's dangerous Executive Orders, the importance of restoring defense and intelligence experts to the National Security Council, and the need to preserve the Affordable Care Act and fight cuts to Medicare and Social Security.  Thanks for your support of my continued focus on White House ethics and Russian interference with our election.   Many of you came to your first town hall meeting because you're looking for ways to be involved, which is why I was inspired to see such a huge turnout at this civic forum. I invite everyone to join me again tomorrow at my Wilton Manors Town Hall.
As Members of Congress, our job is to listen to you. Thanks for the amazing turnout at both of my town hall meetings this weekend. Wherever you are in America, you deserve to be heard!

The people of Palm Beach County shouldn't have to bear the costs of President Trump's visits to Mar-a-Lago. I'm working closely with my colleagues from New York City to ensure that Congress provides funds to reimburse the Palm Beach County Sheriff's office and other law enforcement agencies for these high security expenses.

Flynn's resignation from a job he should never have held does not void the need for a bipartisan investigation; it emphasizes it. Because the President's questionable Russian ties don't end with Flynn, I stand with the Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill who demand a thorough investigation.

The House Judiciary Committee just voted to adopt my amendment ensuring that the committee will investigate any threat to the independence or efficacy of the Office of Government Ethics.  From the President's failure to fully divest himself from his businesses, to his adviser's free commercial for a Trump family clothing line, President Trump has already made the Office of Government Ethics one of the most important agencies we have. It is imperative that we have an independent government ethics office shielded from political whims that will keep our government transparent and free of conflicts of interest.   While the President and certain House Republican leaders have disparaged this independent agency and challenged its crucial work, I am thankful that my colleagues on the Committee agree that it is the responsibility of the Judiciary Committee to ensure that OGE can operate without fear of political attacks.

In his news conference today, President Trump berated a reporter who asked him a question about the rise in incidents of anti-Semitism, saying: “It’s not a simple question, not a fair question." When another reporter asked a follow-up question, the President blamed his political opponents for anti-Semitic acts. "It won't be my people," he said.  We know anti-Semitism is on the rise. In fact, an incident occurred recently at a school in my district that shows how these attacks affect real people. (See below.)  Asking the President about anti-Semitism is a fair question because it is a serious concern, and we have the right to expect our President to unequivocally condemn it. Instead of belittling reporters and accusing them of lying, the President should use this opportunity - finally- to condemn anti-Semitism and bigotry in all its ugly forms.  Given what we've seen, I certainly don't expect it. I hope to be surprised.
This wolf is safe at the Smithsonian's National Zoo, but others like her aren't so lucky. Shame on the House of Representatives for passing a bill yesterday that will harm Alaskan wildlife.

Today I appeared on MSNBC to discuss many of the President's troubling actions during his first month in office, including his politicization of the National Security Council with Steve Bannon’s appointment and the need for bipartisan investigations into the Administration’s questionable ties to Russia and the President’s failure to fully divest from his company. I also called on the President to do more to respond vigilantly to the surge of anti-Semitism across the country.

I always enjoy visiting local businesses that are engaged in issues that impact our community and nation.   Yesterday I visited Archie MD, a company that received a Small Business Research Grant to continue their innovative work promoting safe opioid prescriptions for children.   I was also pleased to meet with Coastal Risk Consulting, a leader in the industry of combatting climate change. Sea level rise greatly impacts homes and businesses in South Florida, and this firm is working to adapt our cities to this risk.

The President’s mass deportation plan is cruel and ineffective. It is simply horrifying and will leave children without parents, businesses without workers, and communities without those who built them. This dangerous policy will hurt all of us, not just undocumented immigrants. Rather than focusing on removal of dangerous criminals, it will detain Floridians without access to due process or a timely hearing. I oppose this grave injustice, and I will fight it while supporting the need to find bipartisan, comprehensive immigration reform.

As Black History Month ends, I'm reflecting on the inspiring life and meaningful work of Justice Thurgood Marshall. I hope my Senate colleagues will do the same next month as they begin to consider the new Supreme Court nominee.

I invited a constituent from Broward County to join me as my guest at the President's address to Congress tonight because she has a story the President should hear. Her grandson was born with a rare condition, and if not for the Affordable Care Act, he wouldn't have been able to receive necessary care. Nationwide, Americans rely on the ACA's guarantees of coverage regardless of pre-existing conditions, relief from fear of medical bankruptcy, and care without lifetime caps. It's because of stories like this that I oppose repeal, and I urge the President to do the same.

This week marks 23 years since enactment of the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act. The bill has saved lives, but in 2017, it's past time for an update. Congress must address senseless gun tragedies, close background check loopholes, and make our communities safer.

If 100 branches of any institution in this country – any religious site, any business, or God forbid any school - were targeted by bomb threats in such a short period, there should be public outcry and it should rise to the highest levels of concern. A threat to the Jewish community, or any religious community, is a threat to us all. When Jewish institutions and schools are targeted, and when terrorist chat rooms on the internet pick up on targeting Jews, we must take action.  That's why today I led my fellow Co-Chairs of the Bipartisan Task Force for Combating Anti-Semitism in urging President Trump to prepare and implement a comprehensive strategy to combat anti-Semitism. You can read the text of our letter here: http://bit.ly/2miW80b

This weekend, hundreds of Floridians will walk in support of their friends and family who battle eating disorders. I'm proud to have written the first nationwide law supporting eating disorders treatment, which passed in Congress last year. Thanks to the Eating Disorders Coalition and the Alliance for Eating Disorders Awareness for participating in #WeWalk. Recovery is possible!

When I took office in 2010, Bob Levinson, our neighbor from Coral Springs, had already been missing for three years. Bob disappeared in Iran on March 9, 2007. This Thursday will mark 10 years since Bob was last seen on Kish Island.  Over the years, I have gotten to know Bob’s wife Christine and his seven children. This incredible family has now gone an agonizing decade without their husband, father, and grandfather. At every opportunity I had to engage directly with President Obama or senior Administration officials, I urged them to press the Iranians on Bob’s case. And I will continue to urge the Trump Administration to do the same.  I have been humbled by the tremendous support my colleagues in the House of Representatives have given to our efforts on Bob’s behalf, and I stand ready to work with anyone committed to bringing Bob home. It is well past time for Iran to fulfill its years of promises to resolve Bob’s case. Each year, I introduce a Congressional resolution on the anniversary of Bob's disappearance. I had hoped we would not have to do it again this year. But this week, I will go to the House floor to again speak about Bob, and I will not stop speaking out for the Levinson family until Bob is back home in South Florida.
As the House Energy and Commerce Committee holds its hearing on the Republicans' healthcare bill, my thoughts on why I oppose it:

Today marks 10 years since Bob Levinson disappeared in Iran. Each Congress, I've introduced a resolution urging Iran and Administration officials to do more to bring Bob home. I had hoped I wouldn't need to this year. Ten years is far too long. Bob deserves to be home with his family in South Florida.

Today the Levinson family made the statement below. I stand with them, ready to work with this Administration and anyone who is committed to bring Bob home to this family.  "FROM THE WIFE, CHILDREN AND GRANDCHILDREN OF ROBERT LEVINSON, AMERICA'S LONGEST-HELD HOSTAGE IN HISTORY - When is enough enough? It has been 10 years since Robert Levinson, our amazing husband, father and grandfather, was arrested on Kish Island, Iran, and imprisoned. For 10 years the government of Iran has been allowed to dodge and weave every time it was asked to come clean about what happened to Bob and send him home. Where is the outrage of this treatment of an American citizen? For 10 years, over and over and over again, two U.S. Presidents abandoned him, a lifelong public servant. Even Bob's government co-workers and their bosses - they know who they are - ran away when he disappeared, to their lasting shame. Ten years is beyond enough. How much more agony must he withstand? It is time to get Bob Levinson home to his family. And, to Bob, Dad and Grandpa Bob: Stay strong! We know you are alive and trying to come home to us. We love you more than ever. We miss you every hour of the day. We will never, never, ever give up looking for you."

The American people have made it clear: they want a full, fair, bipartisan investigation into President Trump's campaign, business, and White House ties to Russia. As I said in House Foreign Affairs Committee today, I'm calling on all my colleagues to join me in pressing for the answers we deserve.

Meet Adam. Adam’s dad called me today to share his deep concerns for his son’s healthcare under the House Republican health bill.  Adam was injured at birth caused by medical malpractice. He is cortically blind, and is a cerebral palsy quadriplegic. Needless to say, the trauma that Adam and his family experienced at birth has only been compounded by crushing medical bills.  Like half of all Americans, Adam's family was covered by an employer-sponsored insurance plan when he was born. But after he was injured, his mom stayed home to care for him and lost her coverage through work. At the time, the individual insurance market was expensive, included annual and lifetime caps, and allowed insurers to deny coverage based on preexisting conditions. After the Affordable Care Act, Adam’s family was able to find a plan in the individual market that provides the coverage he needs.   Adam’s health costs are still a heavy burden, but if the Republican proposal becomes law it will repeal consumer protections that ended annual and lifetime caps on coverage and prevent insurance companies from price gouging Americans based on their health history. Millions of Americans will be completely priced out of coverage.  Adam’s story is like so many others that I’ve heard in the days leading up to today’s vote on the Republican health bill. His family deserves access to coverage even though they are likely to need more care. And every American deserves the same protections when an unfortunate injury, accident, or diagnosis happens to them.   Life is unpredictable. Our health is precious, and our society should guarantee that all Americans are protected against discrimination based on their health status. That’s why I am voting no on this bill, and why I will continue to fight for expanded access to insurance coverage and lower health care costs for all Americans.

The House just voted to pass the disastrous Trumpcare bill. As I told these Planned Parenthood advocates just moments ago, this bill is cruel, it's wrong, and we won't forget that Republicans voted to make being a woman a pre-existing condition again.

From cancer to pregnancy and diabetes to heart disease, half the population will face price gouging based on their health history. The American people want better healthcare; they don’t want higher costs, less coverage, and cuts that will jeopardize Medicare and Medicaid.  TrumpCare will allow insurance companies to discriminate against women, charge seniors five times more than younger consumers, hinder our fight against drug overdoses and addiction, and end requirements for essential health benefits like emergency room and mental health care in all health plans. With this vote, Republicans have chosen to put healthcare out of reach for millions.  But beyond the substance, the process has been entirely undemocratic. Republicans locked the American people out of the process, drafting this proposal behind closed doors, holding hearings in the middle of the night, and refusing to wait for an updated report from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office so that we know even more about the terrible damage this bill will do.   I hope the American people are watching and will hold Congress accountable. I voted no, and I will continue to fight for expanded coverage and reduced costs so that all Americans have the right to access the care they need.

On the eve of President Trump's visit to Israel, I am sharing the letter that Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen and I sent to the President last week. We hope the President's trip is successful in taking steps toward peace.  "Dear Mr. President:  We are hopeful that your upcoming visit to Israel and Saudi Arabia will be fruitful and help pave the way toward direct negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians and, with that, hopefully usher in an era of broad acceptance of Israel in the region.  As you and your representatives explore ways to help lay the foundation for a lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians, it is important to remember that the only path toward a meaningful peace resulting in two states for two peoples, a democratic Jewish state of Israel and a demilitarized Palestinian state, is through direct bilateral negotiations without preconditions. History shows that Israel has been willing to enter into talks and make painful sacrifices for peace if and when it believes there is a sincere and capable partner with whom it can negotiate. Unfortunately, at times when Israel has taken significant steps toward peace, Palestinian leaders have refused to even respond to meaningful proposals.  We hope you urge the Palestinian Authority leadership to take a number of important steps toward lasting peace. First, the Palestinian Authority must cease its glorification of terror and its incitement to violence against Israel. The Palestinian Authority must cease payments to the families of terrorists who are, or were, in Israeli jail or to the families of those who were killed in their efforts to perpetrate terror. These kinds of payments only incentivize terrorism. It must cease to name buildings, schools and town squares after terrorists who have murdered innocent civilians. Ultimately, for a true and lasting peace, the Palestinian leadership must educate the next generation for peace and coexistence, not support for terrorism.  And finally, the Palestinian Authority must cease efforts to isolate and delegitimize Israel and the United Nations and other international bodies, including its efforts to circumvent direct negotiations by seeking unilateral statehood through these bodies.  As Members of Congress deeply committed to the U.S. - Israel relationship, we look forward to continuing our cooperation with Israel on a broad array of issues. We value our shared commitment to human rights and democracy, and we remain hopeful that meaningful peace will result in lasting security and prosperity for both Israel and the Palestinians.  Mr. President, your trip presents an important opportunity to lay the foundation for a return to direct negotiations, with the goal of a lasting peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians. We stand ready to assist you in this important effort."

The President’s budget is morally bankrupt, cruelly demonizes the needy, and is premised on phony economic theories and farcical math. The budget would cut life-saving programs at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that lead our country’s response to epidemics at home and abroad and our search for vaccines and cures to deadly diseases. The National Cancer Institute alone would lose $1 billion compared to last year’s budget. And crucial funding for scientific and medical grants across the government would be drastically reduced.  Despite the President’s enormous defense budget increases, this budget will not make Americans safer. Ignoring scientific consensus, the President wants to eliminate important climate change programs that engage with the private sector and international partners to reduce emissions and respond to the impacts of climate change, impacts we are already facing in South Florida. And at a time when more Jewish students are reporting incidents of anti-Semitism on college campuses across the country, the President wants to weaken the Department of Education’s Civil Rights division that oversees religious-based crimes in schools.   For Floridians, this budget would be particularly painful. The President offers no funding for FEMA’s flood hazard mapping program, a crucial service for South Floridians living in flood-prone areas. The President’s budget cuts nearly $9 billion from our public education system, including teacher training programs and after school services for lower-income students. And an EPA program that helps monitor threatening levels of nutrients in the Everglades would be wiped out.  And in a cold, brazen, and unprecedented move, the President explicitly calls out a single organization – Planned Parenthood – by name to restrict it from providing essential health programs for millions of women like cancer screenings and maternity check-ups.  Just like so many of his other broken promises, the President’s budget isn’t a foundation for ‘American Greatness’ but rather a recipe for weakness, destitution, and devastation.

There are several forms of Irma recovery assistance available to individuals and businesses in Broward and Palm Beach counties. Here's what you need to know:  1) Individual Assistance funds are available from FEMA. These funds can be used to cover medical, child care, household items, moving, and clean-up expenses. Apply online at https://www.disasterassistance.gov/ or by calling 1-800-621-3362.  2) Businesses and residents may be eligible for low-interest federal disaster loans from the Small Business Administration. Types of loans include: -Business Physical Disaster Loans: Any business or organization located in a declared disaster area and that incurred damage during the disaster may apply for a loan to help replace or restore damaged property. -Economic Injury Disaster Loans: If you are in a declared disaster area and have suffered economic injury regardless of physical damage, you may qualify for an Economic Injury Disaster Loan. -Home and Person Property Loans: If you are in a declared disaster area and are the victim of a disaster, you may be eligible for financial assistance from the SBA, even if you don't own a business. -Military Reservists Economic Injury Loans: If you have an essential employee who is a military reservist called to active duty, SBA provides loans to help eligible small businesses with operating expenses.  Apply here: https://disasterloan.sba.gov/ela.   3) Disaster Unemployment Assistance is available to individuals whose employment or self-employment has been lost or interrupted due to Hurricane Irma. This generally includes any worker who, due to Hurricane Irma, no longer has a job or place of work, cannot reach their place of work, or cannot work due to damage to their workplace. File a claim here: https://connect.myflorida.com/Claimant/Core/Login.ASPX.

Today, I sent a letter with over 180 of my colleagues to President Trump urging him not to decertify the Iran nuclear deal so that we can continue to lead the effort against Iran's dangerous behavior.   We forced Iran to the negotiating table in the first place because of the multilateral sanctions imposed on Iran by the U.S. and our global partners. Now, we need to keep up the pressure on Iran for its support for terrorism, its gross human rights violations, and its ballistic missile weapons program. If President Trump decertifies Iranian compliance and walks away from the nuclear deal right now, it could jeopardize this united front against Iran.   I opposed the Iran deal, but to address the most problematic provisions, including the sunset clauses and full access for inspections, we need to be able to lead these efforts with our global partners.  And we must focus on ensuring that Iran retains no control in Syria, either directly or through its proxy Hezbollah.

The Republican budget just passed by the House is a callous proposal to shut down essential programs like Medicare, steal billions of dollars from middle class Americans’ wallets and funnel it to billionaires, and undermine key national priorities by cutting infrastructure funding and wreaking havoc on our healthcare system.  The Republican budget threatens the most vulnerable among us by cutting Medicaid by $1.1 trillion and Medicare by $487 billion over the next ten years. It proposes $50 billion in cuts to veterans’ benefits and $154 billion in SNAP benefits over the same period. And as we face dire international threats from North Korea and terrorist groups like ISIS, House Republicans want to slash our diplomatic and foreign aid budgets by $11 billion.  This partisan budget ignores so many of the nation’s priorities. We should be working to reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program, which ensures nearly 9 million kids get access to care. We should be setting up a bipartisan Select Committee on Gun Violence to come up with sensible, bipartisan solutions to our gun violence epidemic. And we should be working together - Democrats and Republicans - to improve our healthcare system, not take away essential health benefits like protections for people with pre-existing conditions.   This budget, for the fiscal year that began a week ago, is being rammed through the House just so Republicans can move forward with their tax plan that could save President Trump up to $1.1 billion while making middle class families pay more. The trillions of dollars in tax cuts to corporations and the wealthiest Americans will be paid for on the backs of millions of hard-working Americans. Tens of millions of American families could see higher taxes from this plan. When 80 percent of the tax benefits go to the top one percent of earners, it was clearly written without the required concern for the other 99 percent of Americans.  This House Republican budget is removed from the reality in cities and towns across the country. It does not reflect American values. I am strongly opposed to this budget, and I voted against it.

Because many folks have asked for additional information about the terrible Republican budget I voted against, here’s some detailed information on what that budget includes:  • Ends the Medicare guarantee, calls for replacing Medicare with vouchers toward the purchase of a private health plan • Includes Medicare cuts totaling $487 billion over 10 years • Gradually increases the Medicare eligibility age to 67 • Cuts Medicaid by $1 trillion over 10 years • Cuts student loans by $211 billion and slashes Pell Grants by $76 billion • Burdens taxpayers with a $1.6 billion bill to begin construction on Trump’s border wall with Mexico • Fails to invest in our nation’s crumbling infrastructure • Mandates $50 billion in cuts to veterans’ benefits over the next 10 years • Slashes $154 billion over the next 10 years to SNAP, a program relied on by 43 million Americans  I agree that we should consider the federal deficit. But it’s unconscionable to balance our nation’s budget on the backs of veterans, seniors, and education for our youth while simultaneously backing tax cuts for the wealthiest individuals and corporations.  You can learn find the official bill report here: https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt240/CRPT-115hrpt240.pdf and read about the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office's assessment here: http://wapo.st/2wAGSOk.

When President Obama implemented the Clean Power Plan in 2015, it was a landmark move to curb our pollution. Following the Clean Air Act’s directive to improve air quality as a public health concern, the plan targeted power plants and set individual state targets to reduce carbon emissions by seeking alternative and cleaner energy options. Until today, we were on track to reduce emissions by 32 percent below 2005 levels by 2030.   The Trump Administration’s decision to repeal the Clean Power Plan rule continues to ignore scientific evidence. President Trump has firmly joined the side of the climate deniers who want to ignore reality. In just ten months, we’ve seen the White House drag our country backward as the rest of the world surges forward with climate-friendly policies and investments in renewable energy technology.   The Environmental Protection Agency must be true to its name and not actively work to undermine environmental protections. Climate change is a national security threat – threatening millions of Americans’ homes and businesses, essential infrastructure, and U.S. military bases around the world – and must be treated with the priority and urgency it deserves.

Today’s reports indicate that negotiations between the Palestinian Fatah party and the Palestinian terrorist group Hamas have ended in a reconciliation agreement.   Restoring the Palestinian Authority’s control in Gaza would be a critical step toward improving the lives of the nearly two million Palestinians living under brutal Hamas leadership and the Israeli civilians living in perpetual fear of rocket fire, terror attacks, and cross border kidnappings. However, Hamas’ failure to commit to disarming and renouncing terrorism and violence precludes it from being a legitimate partner.   From the little we know of the details of the agreement, there is no obligation for Hamas to give up its weapons or disband its terrorist military wing. After decades of killing innocent Israelis and pledging to destroy the Jewish State, we have seen no indication that they intend to change. Just this morning a Hamas leader made clear his goal of uniting ‘against the Zionist enterprise.’  Any future Palestinian government that includes Hamas must agree to fully disarm the terrorist group, renounce violence, recognize Israel’s right to exist as a Jewish state, honor existing agreements, and commit to peace and security with Israel. This announced deal does not do that. As Ranking Member of the Middle East and North Africa Subcommittee, I’m going to continue to speak out against Hamas terrorism and its threat to Israel.

Today, I introduced the Keep Americans Safe Act along with Rep. Elizabeth Esty of Newtown, CT and Congressman Ruben Kihuen, Congresswoman Dina Titus, and Rep. Jacky Rosen of Nevada.   Our bill renews the now-expired prohibition on the transfer, importation, or possession of magazines able to hold more than 10 rounds of ammunition.  Thirteen years since the large capacity ammunition ban lapsed, Congress has repeatedly failed to act to protect the American people. Gun owners – whether for hunting or self-defense – have no need for magazines that hold more than ten rounds of ammunition, and restricting it will prevent the scale of mass shootings that we’ve seen all too frequently in recent years.  It will save lives.   It’s time for Congress to wrest itself from the N.R.A.’s clutches and pass sensible legislation to address the gun violence epidemic that just left 58 dead in Las Vegas.

Yesterday, the House of Representatives passed emergency funds to help areas recovering from the devastation caused by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria.  I voted in favor of the bill. The South Florida families and businesses that were hit hard by Hurricane Irma need this aid to help get back on their feet. This appropriation will also ensure that the National Flood Insurance Program continues to pay claims from the hurricanes. As its largest contributor, Floridians should be able to depend on this program.  But this aid package is not enough. Weeks after Hurricane Maria, our fellow Americans in Puerto Rico are struggling to access food and basic aid. Most of the island is still without power, and more than a third of the island has no clean drinking water.  Shamefully, this insufficient relief package comes on the same day that President Trump threatened these American citizens that he may prematurely remove emergency relief workers and first responders from Puerto Rico.  When natural disasters strike – whether in Sonoma, Fort Lauderdale, or San Juan – the American people must be able to turn to Congress for help to recover and rebuild.

Last week, President Trump announced his decision to end cost-sharing reduction payments, a fundamental component of the Affordable Care Act to reduce Americans' healthcare costs.  The President is actively working to hurt American families, and add $194 billion to the deficit to make a political point. Millions of Americans depend on these subsidies to get access to care, and millions more hard working middle-class families will see their premiums increase as a direct result of the President’s action.  According to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, this move will leave one million Americans without health insurance next year, and will lead to an additional 20 percent increase in premiums for most Americans. On top of this, many insurance companies will leave markets entirely, leaving an estimated five percent of current enrollees with no insurance options in their area.  Less than three weeks away from open enrollment under the Affordable Care Act, President Trump has shown that he has no idea what it is like for the millions of Americans with ongoing, expensive health needs and an uncertain future.  As with prior attempts to repeal the Affordable Care Act in Congress, the President's executive order will jeopardize access to care for cancer patients, children born with congenital diseases, expecting mothers, and ailing seniors.  Congress should act quickly, in a bipartisan manner, to protect the progress we’ve made toward helping more Americans afford healthcare and working to expand access to all Americans. The President's executive order and the Ryan-McConnell efforts in Congress make the work ahead so much more difficult.

Today, President Trump declared a public health emergency in response to the widespread opioid epidemic raging through communities across our country. Too many children have lost parents, and too many parents have lost their children. Opioid drug addiction is a heartbreaking disease that cuts through society, affecting people regardless of race, income level, or hometown.  In Florida, an estimated 4,000 people lost their lives last year to opioid overdose. And this crisis is far from over. In the first half of this year an estimated 14 Floridians and 142 Americans nation-wide died each day.  President Trump’s decision to declare a public health emergency will hopefully lead to a wider response by the federal government to this national epidemic. But we must do more. This is a complex problem, and we need to fight it on multiple fronts.  The President’s public health emergency declaration stops short of the recommendations of his opioid commission, which called for declaring a national state of emergency. The federal response to this years-long deeply-rooted crisis demands a robust response. I will continue to fight for additional resources beyond the mere $57,000 remaining in the public health emergency fund unlocked by this declaration. Doing so will require continued bipartisan cooperation and investing in lasting solutions.  It’s also past time for Governor Scott to reconsider his refusal to expand Medicaid, so that 800,000 more low-income Floridians can access care. Too many Floridians have died while Governor Scott has withheld treatment available through Medicaid expansion. Earlier this year, Republican Governor of Ohio John Kasich said, ‘Thank God we expanded Medicaid because that Medicaid money is helping to rehab people.’ Yet, Governor Scott is denying that same assistance to 300,000 eligible Floridians who are already in need of mental health and substance abuse care.   This will be a long battle. It will require more than declarations. But hopefully, this is a first step toward a constructive relationship between the White House and Congress toward a goal that every American, Republicans and Democrats, should share: ending the deadly opioid crisis.

On net neutrality-  Equality and openness are the foundation of what makes the internet great. Rules that prevent big corporations from leveraging their power to disadvantage competitors, gouge consumers, and slow innovators have created countless opportunities for nearly all Americans.  Ending net neutrality would undermine those rules by allowing internet service providers to block or slow down traffic that they don’t like or that they aren’t making money from.   Big business shouldn’t be able to put a thumb on the scale to determine who gets to have their voices heard and who gets access to what information.   We must demand public hearings to let all Americans have their voices heard, and we can’t let a bare majority of the FCC ruin the internet for everyone.

Last night’s event came only a week after a horrific terror attack on a Sufi mosque in Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula, in which over 300 worshippers, including children, were killed. We mourn the tragic loss of life and pledge our commitment to help Egypt and our allies fight against those who wish to attack innocent civilians and destabilize nations.  The Sadat anniversary serves as a reminder of the bravery and strong leadership of President Sadat, who took an unpopular but vital step to bring peace to the region. Forty years later, as the region continues to strive for peace, more leaders should learn from President Sadat’s courageous act. Moments ago, I voted against the House Republican spending bill, a short-term stop-gap measure that funds the government only until January 19, 2018.  I cannot support a spending bill that kicks the can down the road while Republican leaders refuse to address important bipartisan priorities. Republican delay tactics are putting millions of Americans at risk.   Before leaving Washington, we should have acted to provide long term stability to the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP). We should have voted on the DREAM Act before the end of the year to provide a permanent legislative solution to the 800,000 DREAMers who are our friends and neighbors. We should have urgently provided the resources necessary to stop the tragic loss of life from the opioid epidemic; a crisis that claimed 63,000 lives in 2016 and continues to devastate South Florida and communities around the nation. We should have adequately provided recovery assistance that is still desperately needed in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. The American people deserve more from their Congress.    To govern is to compromise for the sake of the greater good of our nation. This stop-gap funding bill ignores the priorities of the American people. While I voted against this empty, short-term bill, I hope that my Republican colleagues enter the New Year determined to work with Democrats to find bipartisan solutions to the significant challenges ahead.

Today, the UN General Assembly criticized the U.S. decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.  In the introduction to today’s resolution, Yemen’s Permanent Representative to the United Nations, Khaled Hussein Mohamed Alyemany, said that the 'Israeli occupation is the source of all instability in the region.'  He could not have made it more obvious that today’s resolution was just another illustration of the unhealthy obsession with Israel at the UN.  Israel is not the source of the horrific Civil War ravaging Alyemany’s own country, Yemen, where decades of internal strife are now being inflamed by regional intervention from Iran and Saudi Arabia.  Israel was not the source of the Arab Spring that led to the overthrow of repressive autocratic regimes across the region and subsequent instability from unrealized promises of revolution.  Israel is not the source of the war in Syria in which the Assad regime, aligned with Iran, Hezbollah, and Russia, has killed more than half a million Syrians and displaced millions more.   Today’s UN General Assembly vote is another example of this important international organization being sadly undermined by its obsessive focus on Israel.  Today’s resolution wrongly suggests that the President’s announcement on Jerusalem somehow, ‘altered the character, status or demographic composition of the Holy City of Jerusalem.’   Recognizing that Jerusalem is Israel’s capital does not change the reality on the ground nor does it preclude direct negotiations that can lead to the establishment of a future Palestinian state living side-by-side with Israel.  Nothing the U.S. said changes the importance of Jerusalem to the three monotheistic faiths, nor does it prevent the ability to practice one’s faith in the ancient city.  Tomorrow is the holiest day of the week in Islam and thousands of Muslims will continue to pray on the Temple Mount at the al Aqsa Mosque.  On Friday night and Saturday, thousands of Jews will welcome the Sabbath at the Western Wall, the Kotel.  And on Christmas Eve Sunday and on Christmas Monday, Christians will pray at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre.  The President's announcement does not change the status quo in the Old City where the Islamic Waqf, under the custodianship of Jordan, manages the Muslim holy sites; the Israeli Rabbinate manages the Jewish holy sites; and Christian Churches manage the Christian holy sites.  That is why Ambassador Haley was right to vote against the resolution and to veto a similar resolution in the UN Security Council.  I hope that we can now move beyond this distraction and urgently return to a process that advances a sustainable two-state solution.  We need to see change at the UN. We need membership standards for the UN Human Rights Council so that human rights abusers cannot use the platform to hide their own human rights violations. And we need to reform the council by removing Standing Agenda Item 7 that is used to repeatedly target Israel instead of addressing real crises.  Ambassador Haley and I have spoken directly about the urgent need to make these changes.   But in order to effect this change we must remain engaged at the UN. I hope America does not shy away from its critical role as a global leader at the UN and beyond. The best way to protect our national security and advance the interest of America and our allies is to be a leader on the world stage rather than retreating within our own borders.
